oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary of 1912 health report for Gallatin written by the City Health Officer, Dr. W. N. Lackey. The report statistically addresses mortality rates and births and provides a partial breakdown by sex, race, and age. It examines causes of death, with attention given to the decreasing threat from tuberculosis and the increasing threats from typhoid and improper water sources. It lists sanitary recommendations and emphasizes the need for a sewage system in Gallatin.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Twentieth century public health records for Tennessee reflect an increasing emphasis on disease prevention and the increasing state responsibility for public health and education. Following major outbreaks of cholera and yellow fever across the state from 1832 through 1873, a State Board of Health was created for Tennessee in 1875, and many jurisdictions hired health officers. Localities became more involved in issues of public health and vital statistics, as this broadside illustrates.
